title: LKE Standup 10/06
content:
phillip: Yeah.

evangeline: Identity, Sarah. So I was looking at. Actually, I kind of posted my update in Project Exponent.

evangeline: I'm probably not going to enumerate it. I'm going to assume everyone read my post, but I was hoping that it's one of the things we can nail down. This then.

JohnnyD: Yeah, I think that's probably more important technical decisions to make right now.... Happy to talk to it.... Glitter ones. Update first.

evangeline: I can. Popcorn to johnny.

JohnnyD: Sure thing. On my side, working through the eval specifically focused on trying to get tasks in place. There are some changes from Brent Navan over the weekend. Those are great helpful. But this code base got a couple weird things merged in where we had same prompt in three different places. So honestly, I think I've spent most of my day fighting those fires so that I can actually work on clearly solving the task eval. So I've been working through those with Philip.

JohnnyD: Yeah.... So that's the main thing I'm working on.

phillip: Yeah, I've just been making prompt updates. I think we're getting closer, but I think there's a chance that.

phillip: We'll hit a wall and don't really have a way to improve from there. So I think two.

phillip: I think the trickiest thing is I don't think I really understand when something's a subtask.

phillip: Of another. In fact, it may be kind of hard for a third party to actually evaluate that.

phillip: Because we have a lot more context on what we mean when we say set up new Grapevine tenant.... And maybe.

phillip: This is where corp context actually comes. This maybe is where we add back the MCP is It would use that to understand what it means by tenant and then. Yeah, so anyway.

phillip: I kind of wished that I could have a yes or no answer as to if we feel like we can solve this eval using simple stuff by now, but I think we'll have it by the end of the day.... We just keep tweaking.... Until it feels like we're not making progress.

evangeline: Josh, Dylan's got tape.

evangeline: Do you want to give an update next?

evangeline: Maybe brat next.

Brad: Yeah, I can forgot what Cough canyon is. Sex. I think I'm going to do a lot of talking and I'm a bit sick. Been working with Daniel on kind of zooming out and thinking about what project management software may look like in this age of AI. So thinking beyond kind of just an integration with linear.... And thinking like what?

Brad: What we can do now that we couldn't do in the past. Because LINEAR was perhaps designed to look like a successor to jira, with better design, better execution and.

Brad: We can add some automations on top of that, for sure, but we can also kind of think about what does this look like more broadly, what might this process look like more broadly in the future? And that's kind of where we've been ideating a little bit. So once we're all done with status. I can talk through some of our thoughts so far and see if anything resonates with a group, if there's anything that we want to kind of zoom into and maybe try poking at or building or if there are any areas that we want to dismiss as well.

Brad: And I'm going to go grab a cough candy. Still listening, though.

daniel: Yeah, for me, I would say it's basically the same as Brad.... Yeah. Nothing else.

evangeline: Okay. In that case, let's do the design explorations once Brad is back, and then after that, we can, I guess, especially engineers can stay back to talk about the eval.

Brad: Sounds good.... Okay?

Brad: So what we've been.

Brad: Yeah. What we've been thinking is a few different things.

Brad: So one of the main questions that we don't necessarily need to answer now, but something that we should form an opinion on is do we care?... About the defensibility.

Brad: Or durability of a solution that's built on something like linear exclusively? Or are we interested in.

Brad: A broader approach to project management. Knowing that.... We could face some of the same challenges that we faced with Gather.

Brad: In that there's a large feature set to tackle for even like a minimum viable project management system. But. Yeah, go ahead, Philip.

phillip: I think we should consider ourselves having very little constraints right now.

phillip: Because there's a good chance. I feel like a lot of the. Unlike with Gather, I think there's a good chance that a lot of the features built that linear built are irrelevant in the new age.

phillip: In which cases like proper disruption rather than in the past, we had to just straight up clone a lot of features, which was annoying.

Brad: Agree 100%. Yeah, I think irrelevant is a good way to put it.

Brad: Sort of task managers or ticketing systems of the past required so much detail and context and manual organization that they did just get neglected and kind of atrophy in the ways that we've all witnessed. And that felt like one of the underlying principles of this project was trying to tackle that head on. So what we've tried to do is kind of take the core entities and distill them down to what we would need.

Brad: Representation for. So, like, projects are a thing, tasks are a thing. Of course, features are things. Maybe two levels of hierarchy where you have, like, tasks.

Brad: And and features that live above them. But we also think that nominating or promoting requirements to being a first class document is something that would help facilitate a lot of interesting things. So requirements we see like being checked into repos at times, or maybe they're a separate file. But the notion of having requirements that are constantly referenced with your features and your. Your tasks that are being executed and seeing where they may differ.

Brad: And being able to automatically update requirements based on discussions from transcripts, meetings, slot conversations, etc. Is something that's pretty interesting.... Too. So with that preamble, I'll share my screen.... And talk through some of the stuff that we've been sketching.

Brad: So some of the ideas why existing tools fail.

Brad: That I think we've talked about. But I'll reiterate here. So manual management and SaaS updates create overhead.

Brad: There are fragmented requirements and decisions. I think this is something that we downplay or maybe haven't talked about a ton in this particular project thus far. But requirements are all over the place. Anything that resembles a product requirements doc is frequently out of date immediately, and then there's just a stream of tickets with no real sense if, like, the tickets actually map back to requirements or not, if they're essentialist or not, if they should be prioritized or they shouldn't. Which ones are interdependent or related to one another.

Brad: And decisions as well. So decisions, we should be having a decision log of source and those should feedback into requirements so that we have something to reference our tickets and features against. Otherwise it's just like it's all just noise deleted. Insights into proactive planning. Like that's something too. And then there's just generally high configuration complexity, which all of us have felt with tools like linear, especially.

Brad: Some of the first principles, then, in what a solution could look like is unifying all these project artifacts into a single source of truth. Um, the immediate thing that comes to mind with this is.

Brad: This XK CD of how standards proliferate. I hope you've all seen this before.... But it definitely feels this way in some regard.

Brad: But hopefully one of the differences in this new AI first age is that a new standard can be extremely simple and mostly a read only representation of data or a reflection of existing data that's out there in the ether from other integration sources, rather than it being a discrete source of truth itself.... We want to minimize manual overhead through AI automation, of course.

Brad: Another thing that I just touched on was treating requirements, decisions and tasks as first class objects. Requirements and decisions, especially.... Are maybe less commonly captured in tools like linear and similar.

Brad: And then designing for extensibility. So we're talking about a lot of this in a software engineering context, but.... Think ideally.... A solution of this sort transcends industry.

Brad: And it would apply to home building as well, which also has project managers, which also has task tractors, which also has so many of these similar things that are going to look a little bit different in the age of AI. Maybe there's not agents completing as many home building tasks as there are in software, but there's still all the same problems, and that's in a lot of different industries.

Brad: So at a really high level, what some of these flows may look like is.... This is.

Brad: Extremely low fidelity and predicated that a project exists already. So we haven't sketched out what like a project creation flow may look like that could be generated from a meeting artifact or other things, but just imagine some sort of index. I have also delineated between projects and areas inspired by I think I'VE mentioned this before to many of the folks on this call. Like the second Brain para method from Thiago Forte projects being short term with a distinct end date. So for example, building the minimum viable product of an app, whereas areas require continuous efforts over long periods like customer support is something that for a product company probably doesn't end. It's just a continuous effort. And we think that that will require a slightly different flow or slightly different.... Way of handling it in the app, but could nonetheless be in it.

Brad: Moving on. This is not super interesting, but like a project overview page is probably for a particular project is probably going to look like a Gantt chart.

Brad: It'll probably have dashboardy type modules within it, and those dashboardy type modules could show like a decision log. It could show upcoming time off from people who are working on the project. It could show recently completed tasks, etc. Nothing super groundbreaking here, but this is sort of where you would most likely land if you were of that sort of manager or leader profile or Persona. And we're trying to get a vibe check on how a project is going.

Brad: But then we get into some of the more interesting stuff. So if you were to drill down from a project overview into different project subpages or tabs,

Brad: You can imagine a details tab which is where the requirements are treated like a first class citizen. So we think that requirements should be versioned using git or git like mechanism. This isn't necessarily saying that they should be checked into the repo, but they could be. I spent most of my career in client services and needing to generate change logs or change orders all the time because clients change their mind or scope changed or things happened.

Brad: We recognize that this happens at product companies as well, too. And we need a source of truth for what the actual requirements for an app are. Otherwise, our tickets have nothing to reference. We don't know if they're actually moving the needle.

Brad: They're just sort of a stream of noise. So the idea of versioning requirements and keeping them as a source of truth for all of the work towards a particular feature is interesting. As part of this, there should be a decision log and a decision queue that shows where change is originated from.

Brad: This is sort of a common thread that we like very loosely illustrated with this floating circle in the bottom right is there should be project manager agent of sorts that in this context may help you identify gaps and requirements, opportunities for scope reduction, dependencies, etc. But that's sort of an aside. Just assume that there's some LLM that has all of this context, plus potentially more corporate context from Grapevine or other tools that could answer questions too.... But the way that.

Brad: Changes to requirements happen could be interesting. So in this case, there could be an action that happens in Slack, for example.

Brad: Where Hyunji may say, hey, wouldn't it be cool if we did xyz? And then Luigi says, okay, let's do it.

Brad: And then an agent chimes in and says, you know, should I add this to the requirements and create a task or tickets feature, whatever. It would be interesting to have that sort of decision flow baked into a platform where the result ends up as sort of. I think we even talked about this as like a Tinder style. Ui. You know, imagine like, there's a decision log that, a decision queue that you have to go through to decide whether the scope is in, the scope is out, and you're reviewing this as a team, and it's almost like a swipe right, swipe left. If things were. Were that easy, or you could drill down into further discussion something they require it. And if something were to be included, for example, then you're seeing a diff of when the requirement stock was materially updated with more scope or less scope or whatever.... Then there could be some.

Brad: Constant validation loop where requirements are referenced against outstanding features and tasks to make sure that the outstanding features and tasks or the TO dos actually encompass all of the requirements.

Brad: And this too is something that it feels like sorely missed from our current flows. Then maybe this is happening with webhooks whenever the requirements change, or whenever tickets change or to dos change. But then you're sort of keeping this constant reference loop that may flag like, hey, these requirements are missing. Or hey, these tickets actually don't service any of these requirements.

Brad: Why are they being completed? And can we down down prioritize them, for example? But those are like, those are some ideas around what tracking requirements and a decision log as first class citizens could look like.

Brad: Into what actual to dos or tickets should look like.

Brad: We think that in order for them to be used, they need to feel extremely simple. Some people prefer paper to do lists like I typically have one, or I do have one almost every day. Some people do live out of linear, and some people live out of other tools as well. But linear can feel really burdensome because of all the data that it requires to actually create small granular to dos. And so people often just don't.

Brad: But in the age of context awareness, AI auto classification and knowledge of requirements and the like, we should be able to just take plain text tasks or to dos and either assign them or group them into features, reference them against the requirements and create a list in that way. So if you have features in this context, naming TBD may act as parent collections of tasks, and tasks are atomic ish work units with statuses. But tasks may be created through several means. So maybe there's some natural language processing in chat. I think that's what some of the vowels are looking at now. Like maybe there's some just discussion in pertinent slack channels, and those are turned into tasks. I think that's what we're looking at doing right now. Or some of the stuff that we're looking to do right now is linear. But I think there could also be mirrors, so impertinent linear projects, if linear were being used.

Brad: Tickets from Linear or Jira or GitHub issues would also show up as tasks in this queue in this project management app, but then they could also show up by way of actions.

Brad: And this is sort of akin to an activity log. So I used an example with the design team the other day.

Brad: Where this is like a month or two back where I think I had done something like 40 PRs in the month and three of them had linear tickets because I just didn't bother creating linear tickets with the rest. Like, it's just annoying and an extra step to do. But I still want record of that. Action because it was work that I did that day.

Brad: And it should also be checked that it is in service of a broader goal which maybe enumerated in a requirement stock. So when that's happening, a new PR on GitHub should show up as a task in this app, and maybe it shows up with a status and review if it were just opened or Maybe it's complete if the PR was merged. The same thing is true in other contexts, where a designer may share a slack message with a link to a figma and that should show up as a task. And these again can be thought of as something like an activity log. This is where we could replace one of the chores of standup. What you're saying, you know, what you're working on, all this stuff, it should just be a sum of your task status.

Brad: For that given day or a week or whatever the time frame may be. Additionally, something that I don't think we captured here, or maybe raised as a question is like should tasks be suggested to ICs based on inference? And that could be from inference of project requirements. It could be shown that like a feature is being burned down and there's only a handful of tasks left, and it sees that your queue is empty. And it could suggest in this queue, hey, why don't you tackle these things next? There could be some sort of intelligent or intelligence or prompt around doing that, which would be interesting. Again, coordinated by some sort of agentic PM that has all the context, knows what people are working on, says, hey, someone is, you know, Brad is falling behind. Can you help him with these tasks? Because this deadline is coming up. For example,

Brad: And those could show up in one skew. But this needs to be so clean and so simple and so easy to do and useful that people will actually ideally use it. Because for some, maybe thinking of, like, people.

Brad: Like business analysts or sort of data sciencey roles. They may not have integrations that show exactly what they're doing all the time, and they may not want to create linear tickets for it. But if we can manage a to do list for them that's super clean and easy, and that is constantly referencing overall requirements for a North Star, then maybe they'll be inspired to use something like that as well.

Brad: And the last tab is just. The last tab, in this context at least, is just a team tab. And this is probably pretty simple, but it should show who is allocated to a given project or effort now, what their availability is like if they're going to get engaged in Spain next week, like Daniel.

Brad: No, just kidding. You saw it, but I'm bugging him about it. And then maybe skills are relevant past work or knowledge, so other contexts that could be useful and that would feed into again some sort of agentic PM that helps take these requirements and map them into features and tasks and keep things moving along.

Brad: There's a super long winded prd that describes this in more detail here. This is generated by OpenAI chatgpt. Whatever.

Brad: I haven't. I just did this half. Well, chatgpt to this half an hour ago or 45 minutes ago or so. I haven't read through it.

Brad: In complete detail. So I don't even know if it's all accurate, but I did prompt prompted and had to ask clarifying questions and such. And then there's sort of a condensed version of that same sort of thing over on the left.

Brad: But. Yeah, I'll open the floor now for thoughts, discussion.... What aligns, what doesn't, etc.

phillip: Yeah. So I think this is exactly what we all had in our minds in terms of what the smoothest, coolest version of new AI, New World AI Project management could be.

phillip: I think the thing I'd be curious about the most is to start to get concrete enough that we get really excited about a thing that we could actually build and ship.

phillip: And get feedback, and within the next.... Ideally, like three months, I guess.

phillip: It's like if you had to choose a few of these features and it could be a standalone app, maybe for just a single team, maybe even just for a single project. Just to simplify it for the first version that people can try. I'm curious what we'd simplify it down to.

Brad: Yeah. To me, it's a first class notion of requirements.... And first class notions of features and tasks.... And those being.

Brad: It auto updated, for lack of a better term, but those being kept live.

phillip: Has to be, like, super accurate, right? I think that's probably the biggest aha moment.... Is like, wow, I don't need to think about this anymore. This thing's got it covered for me.

Brad: Yeah, I think it's like. I mean, it would look like and feel like working with some of the best PMS of your life who never took a vacation.

phillip: Right? Or also just reading every single thing possible, including your GitHub PRs.... Pms never do.

Brad: The all knowing wizard of oz. Pm.

phillip: Yeah, and actually like a PM that you don't have to talk to that much either. Even the best PMS you ever worked with, you still kind of need to tell them.... Like this is what I did. This is why I haven't done yet.

Brad: I think that is, yeah.

phillip: Sorry. No, that was my full thought.

Brad: Yeah. That is one of the marks of, like, the best PMS I've worked with is they aren't bugging you for things because they know they've absorbed the context through the available means. And I don't have to be like, okay, where are we at on this?

phillip: One.

phillip: Piece of input I had on the requirements and decisions.

phillip: There should probably also be, like, an input.... Because oftentimes people or customers provide input that you've already considered.

phillip: So it's not actually like, a pending decision. It's actually just, like, pending input, I guess.

phillip: It would be actually kind of cool to organize that in a place where it's like, this is just input. We know you've seen this before, or we know its input on not the highest priority part of this project, but it's just like in this other place for you to just scroll as well.

Brad: Do you think those would be rejected decisions?

phillip: Well, they may be deferred decisions. Like maybe their decisions were. The team collectively doesn't feel the need to make a decision about it now.

phillip: And maybe you don't like. There's two ways you can think about that. You either think about that as we made the decision not to consider it now.

phillip: Or you could just consider it as like this is just pending input.

phillip: One last thing I loved was I like the idea of a Tinder style UI for making decisions, actually, because.... Oftentimes, a live project can.

phillip: It's so hard to stay focused because random things come up at all sorts of times and you're making decisions at all sorts of times versus it'd be cool if it was just like a one place where you just made all the decisions and all the context for each decisions right there for you.

Brad: Yeah, I think that.

Brad: I would love to see that this is where potentially integrating with something like, I don't know if any other video platform. So like if there were first class support for something like this and gather and you could have real time transcriptions feeding into this sort of thing, then you were able to circle back at the end. To like, okay?... What decisions do we need to make? Let's go through these action items as a group.

phillip: Yeah, that's cool.

Brad: It'd be really neat.

phillip: Yeah, and then you also mark down the reasoning for each decision, in fact.

phillip: This could potentially be one of the most important things for training a company specific decision maker in the future, because you actually have a single log of all the decisions that were made, plus the reasoning as a group as to why you made some decision or not.

phillip: And then maybe the AIs would learn and start to make all the easy decisions for you.

phillip: Or if you always come back to one principle for making decisions, learns to do that. That's really cool.

Brad: Yeah, I captured a few notes there, but feel free to annotate or edit.

evangeline: Yeah, I think I really liked.

evangeline: A bit about autonomously capturing changes across your entire stack. I think, again, that's something that we were pre aligned on and that was also what was in my brain.

evangeline: I was already, like, the decision log, like the queue stuff.

evangeline: Because I think one thing that has always been quite difficult tracked across a suite of tools is changes are happening across multiple conversations, sometimes even in ones that I'm not part of.

evangeline: And it's pretty cool to be able to see in one place, okay, all the changes that are happening across the project. So everyone's on the same page.

evangeline: One thing that I had. I kind of thought when I was looking at this proposal,

evangeline: I think we need to be careful about how, well, I guess what utility this tool is bringing.

evangeline: I'm not sure what the customers exactly. I'm not sure customers want. It's perfect.

evangeline: Log of every single thing that's happened within their project or perfectly organized background. I think the ultimate paid point we need to help them solve is this project being steered in a way that increases velocity or improves delivery or what is the ultimate.

evangeline: Like, how would their project be different now that they're using this tool? I think some things around automating, standups and so on, that's important. But if this tool is able to steer projects because it's now able to surface information that was not easily discoverable before, it's able to connect the dots between things, or it's able to be like, this is a dependency and you're putting a project at risk because you're prioritizing the wrong things.... I think that could be pretty leveraged.

evangeline: Yeah, that's my vague, immediate feedback. I guess basically what I'm trying to say is we need to be careful and we might want to be careful not to much on perfect capture, because profile capture is not, probably not what people are asking for. I think what they're asking for is a way to improve delivery.... And capture, like may or may not exactly solve that problem, if that makes sense.

phillip: I think the way that I would reframe that is.... I think the capture needs to be really accurate.

phillip: But it doesn't need to be exhaustive. In fact, it's probably best done if it's, like, prioritized towards what kind of information actually people actually need.

phillip: But yeah, I think it's still worth then drawing the connection between that and why is it actually.... Helping people.... I think making the project ship faster.... Is one value prop. I think the second one is actually just enjoyment of the day.

phillip: Like the day can be a lot more focused. There doesn't need to be as much glue work to get people on the same page and motivated and bought in that an idea is important.

phillip: Less time each individual needs to spend translating all the stuff they talked about into their own to do list less timing.... To connect with other people, making sure everyone knows what's going on.

phillip: And I think that value prop is more like the cursor value prop. Whereas, like, autocomplete didn't actually speed up people in terms of number of hours spent coding, maybe, or it didn't actually speed up the speed of tickets, but it made it a lot more fun. And I think that's still actually a big part of what we're going for is just, like, make work itself just far more fun.

evangeline: Unless you agree that because I was like main value prop.

evangeline: Okay. I think the form factor of autocomplete felt good, but the main value prop was something along the lines of, like, you're a better engineer because now you're.

evangeline: Either, like doing things faster or closer, is able to pull in patterns.... That are more aligned with the code base.... You're able to solve problems, like, more correctly.

phillip: Well.

evangeline: Autocomplete is more of a form factor thing, isn't it?

phillip: I think if you were to ask, like, why did it blow up?... And specifically, why did they get so much word of mouth?... I think it's because people loved using it.

phillip: And I don't think anyone was telling their friends. I'm actually getting X number more tickets done per day.

phillip: I think they're just saying I can't live without it. And they didn't want more specific than that. And my read is people. It was just more delightful experience.... By a lot, actually.

phillip: It's pretty good not to have to type all that random stuff that you used to have to do in the past.

Brad: Yeah, I do think an aspect of it is less friction overall, so you just get stuck less if you're programming with AI. Like, you may have had to go on a rabbit like down rabbit holes previously through Stack Overflow, through asking peers, through digging through GitHub issues or whatever. So it is sort of in a way like removing those barriers that help you focus on the enjoyable aspects or the creative aspects of creative act of building things, which has some overlap with potentially some of the value props that we could offer in an app like this is there is less of all that other stuff and there's more just pure creation, ideally. With like this.

Brad: Amazing product agent who's looking over your shoulder and ensuring that you have sort of gentle guidance, working towards common goals, reference by requirements, who's calling out gaps or related work that may be being worked on by peers.

Brad: Identify. Okay, this. This feature idea was great, and I just reviewed the PR that Evan merged or something. But we should also look at doing XYZ as a result. So let me put some more tickets.

Brad: In service of these new capabilities that are now enabled because of this work. That evangelist checked in.

Brad: Yeah, I think there's some interesting correlations there.

evangeline: You can get.... Life is a pure.... I'm not sure what. I'm escapating this well enough.

phillip: Well. Any good? I think it's kind of hard to dissect exactly why Cursor won, but I think what I'm trying to say is I think we shouldn't underestimate how much value there is in just making someone's day more pleasant, even if it doesn't translate. Into a larger velocity of work getting done.

phillip: Yeah.

Brad: Not having to reiterate your work in standup would make everyone stay more pleasant. I think so. There's a small win there.

phillip: It's going to be really hard for us to quantify energy levels, but if we could, I think we can make a dramatic improvement on that. And I think that's my case. My take for a lot of tools that were successful is that's what they mostly did.

evangeline: Okay, let me go and think about this a little bit. I think one thing, one reflection I had.

evangeline: Trying out a ton of different products lately is like, okay, and this is like a totally tangential example. Not going to relate a project, but one thing I notice about Snowflake, for example.... You can't even freaking invite a user on Snowflake.... And Snowflake is this, like, multibillion dollar business, right?

evangeline: And I'm just like, wow, there is something so valuable about this product that even if there are some parts of it where the friction is so high, people still want to use it.

evangeline: I guess, principally, I'm trying to think.... Like.

Brad: You muted. There you go.

evangeline: Oh, I'm not sure why I got muted randomly.... Sorry. Where did I get.

phillip: I think I understand your point. Your point is, like, if we could go after a snowflake thing, we should.... Which I agree with, actually.

evangeline: Yeah. I think my field was something that is like, oh, this thing is the best tool ever because it's so smooth to use.

evangeline: It almost feel like a counter example of what successful products are typically like, if that makes sense.

phillip: Well, I don't think it's a counterexample. I think it's just a different win condition.

phillip: I think there's different kinds of product. Like Zoom was another example of it's video chat that just works.

phillip: Everyone technically had a video chat, but the quality is what made the big difference. Slack was also an example of There are plenty of chats out there, but Slack was the highest quality one. So I think there's different tools out there that either win based off of details and quality and smoothness, but there are definitely the ones like Salesforce and Snowflake.... That win purely off of.... A business job, it gets done.... And actually explicitly not on the user experience.

evangeline: Now to help.

phillip: And I think I agree with you. If we could find a business use case that is so compelling, people would use us even if we weren't high quality.

phillip: The thing we should go after. Because if you marry it with quality is even better.

phillip: That's how we can think. That pushes us. I think big enough.

evangeline: Yeah, I think maybe my overall take is like, if we are going from a pure quality, light, quality of life, ease of use of angle, we are almost playing on hard mode.... Like.

phillip: It also just doesn't seem like it's utilizing AI strongly enough.... That's the only angle we have here.

phillip: I think we can come up with something here that feels, like, super new and you can't live without once you do it.

Brad: I didn't think that this was playing on purely like a quality angle at all, really. I thought it was the main value prop being you have a simplified aggregate of work being done and referencing that against versioned requirements that are kept up to date based on company context, conversations, etc.

Brad: I don't think we'll design the best can't chart or whatever. Like we could maybe, or do other stuff, but I don't. I don't think that is a value prop at all. I think it's all of these other connective tissues.

evangeline: Yeah, sorry, my comment here wasn't really to the overall proposal. I totally agree with you Brett. I think my response was more to the possible value props. Less blue, more enjoyment point.

evangeline: Because that feels leaning more towards light. Okay. Quality of life.

evangeline: As a value prop instead of, like, a deeply painful problem that we're solving really well.
